article: My Teacher in the School of Life I spent the opening day of school this year at DeMatha Catholic High School in much the same way I spent the first day of classes  _  30 years ago; I sat in Dr Charles E. Offutt's British literature class, listening to him  _  what his seniors would learn and get them excited about the journey they would  _  . I'm the principal of the school now , but for a few minutes I was back in 1975,  _  what the future held. I have been learning from Dr Offutt for 30 of the 51 years he had been teaching at DeMatha. He not only taught me to think, he  _  me, as much by example as  _  that it was my moral duty to do so and to serve  others  . Neither of us could know how our  _  would develop over the years. When I first came back to DeMatha to teach English. I worked for Dr Offutt, the then department chair. After several years, I was  _  department chair, and our relationship changed  _  I thought that it might be  _  chairing the department, since all of my former English teachers were still there, but Dr Offutt  _  me throughout. He knew when to give me  _  about curriculum, texts and personnel, and when to let me design my own course. In 1997, I needed his advice about leaving DeMatha to become principal at another school. If he had asked me to stay at DeMatha, I might have.  _  , he encouraged me to seize the new  _  . Five years ago, I became the  _  of DeMatha. Once again, Dr Offutt was there for me, letting me know that I could  _  on him as I tried to fill such big shoes. I've learned from him that great teachers have a (n)  _  wealth of lessons to teach.  Even if  his students don't know it yet, I know how  _  they are; I'm still one of them.
